abstract.p: Buffalo Sabres defeat Toronto Maple Leafs, 3-2; other NHL results noted (M)

block.p: SABRES 3, MAPLE LEAFS 2 Dominik Hasek didn't face a shot for more than 20 minutes of play, but the Buffalo goalie was anything but bored as the Sabres jumped back into the last playoff spot.

Hasek wasn't tested much, but came up big when needed, as the Sabres hung on for a 3-2 victory over the visiting Toronto Maple Leafs last night. The victory, combined with Carolina's 3-2 loss at Pittsburgh, lifted Buffalo into eighth place in the Eastern Conference.

Hasek wasn't tested much, but came up big when needed, as the Sabres hung on for a 3-2 victory over the visiting Toronto Maple Leafs last night. The victory, combined with Carolina's 3-2 loss at Pittsburgh, lifted Buffalo into eighth place in the Eastern Conference.
With 81 points, the Sabres are
1 point ahead of the Hurricanes and 2 ahead of idle Montreal. Buffalo and Montreal have three games remaining, while Carolina will play only two more.

Dixon Ward snapped a 2-2 tie with 4 minutes 43 seconds left in the first period, while Buffalo's stifling defense did the rest, limiting the Maple Leafs to eight shots over the game's final 40 minutes.

The Sabres were so dominating that they held Toronto without a shot in the second period. It is the first time the Maple Leafs have had a period without a shot on goal in the 45 years the league has been keeping record of the statistic.

''It was a very, very important game,'' Hasek said. ''I just tried to stay focused, and I was focused for all 60 minutes. It didn't matter if they didn't have any shots, you can't relax against a team like Toronto.''
While he faced only 20 shots, Hasek made a brilliant game-saving stop, robbing Jonas Hoglund's one-timer from the slot with 6:31 left.
Miroslav Satan and Michael Peca also scored for the Sabres, who have won six of seven.
PENGUINS 3, HURRICANES 2
Aleksei Kovalev scored twice within 33 seconds of the second period as Pittsburgh beat visiting Carolina and strengthened its hold on a playoff spot.
Jaromir Jagr, who returned Saturday after missing two games with a sore back, did not score.
The victory gave seventh-place Pittsburgh 84 points, 3 more than Buffalo. The Hurricanes fell to ninth place.
SHARKS 1, OILERS 0
Niklas Sundstrom scored a short-handed goal at 4:37 of the third period, lifting visiting San Jose to victory over Edmonton.
Edmonton lost the puck in its own end and Sundstrom jammed it past Oilers goalie Tommy Salo for the Sharks' 15th short-handed goal this season, matching the Detroit Red Wings for the league's best.
Steve Shields recorded his fourth shutout of the season, stopping 20 shots.
San Jose, with 83 points, has a three-point lead in the Western Conference over ninth-place Vancouver for the final playoff position. Edmonton is in seventh place with 84 points.
The Oilers had a chance to tie the game, with under six minutes left, when forwards Todd Marchant and Ethan Moreau broke in on a 2-on-1, but Moreau could not beat Shields up high.
FLAMES 2, STARS 2

Phil Housley scored the tying goal with 6:52 left as visiting Calgary rallied from a two-goal third-period deficit to tie Dallas. The point helped the 10th-place Flames in their long-shot pursuit of the eighth and final Western Conference playoff spot.
